awd_titl_txt: REU site in Mechanical Engineering: Energy and the Environment (ME3)
awd_abstract_narration:
The REU Site in Mechanical Engineering: Energy and the Environment (ME3) hosted by the University of Minnesota  (UMN) Department of Mechanical Engineering will provide a diverse cohort of undergraduate students opportunities to engage in engineering research with a focus on energy and the environment complimented by ambitious intergenerational mentoring and professional development opportunities.   Due to the Department's multidisciplinary areas, student research projects are focused on these topics:  air quality, water quality, or energy generation, storage, and transmission. Each project has valuable societal benefit and contributions, for example: clean water through materials development, reduced air pollution through studies of combustion and gas turbines, and energy savings through hybrid wind technology. 

The 10-week summer research program will host 10 college sophomores and juniors with a focus on recruiting from traditionally under-represented segments of the engineering population including women, racial and ethnic minorities, persons with disabilities, and those from colleges without traditional research opportunities. The ME3 program objectives are to: offer hands-on research experience in state-of-the-art laboratory and computing facilities related to energy and the environment, articulate the relationship between research and how it impacts daily life, expose students to mechanical engineering research and student life at a major research university, establish a team mentoring relationship between REU students, graduate students, and faculty, and encourage students to consider graduate school in engineering. The program emphasis on mentoring can lead to a more diverse workforce, not just for the immediate REU participants, but the impact of those participants as future mentors in their own careers. Students will review technical literature, use computer-aided design software, mathematical modeling, fabrication, and experimental testing. The research and professional development activities will help students develop lifelong skills including critical thinking, teamwork, and effective communication. REU students will also give regular project updates to their research teams through weekly progress reports.  At the end of the summer, students participate in a campus-wide REU Research Symposium coordinated by the UMN's Office for Equity and Diversity.  REU alumni will be surveyed annually to obtain post-experience impact related to their academic progress and professional pathway.  A LinkedIn network will be established to maintain contact with REU alumni.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview:

The Mechanical Engineering department at the University of Minnesota offered a ten week summer research experience for four summers with a focus on research related to energy and the environment.  The program components were:

●   research: each participant conducted a research project under the supervision of a faculty member

●   professional development: the program included weekly seminars, workshops, and field trips

●   social: whether offered virtually or in person, students were part of a larger learning community at the University of Minnesota comprised of over 250 other REU students 

●   extended research:  students had the option to continue their research activity by returning to campus or presenting their research at a conference in the following academic year

 

The program was offered entirely virtually during the first summer (2020), hybrid with an on campus option summer 2021, and fully on campus the final two summers (2022, 2023). The program participants were recruited through direct contacts with faculty, staff, administrators, and student leaders at HBCU’s, diversity offices, R3 colleges, and student chapters of SACNAS/AISES/NSBE/SHPE/SWE.  In total 35 undergraduate students participated in the program, all of whom identified as one or more of the following:  underrepresented minority, female, or student at a 2 or 4 year college without a research program.  


Program content and effectiveness were evaluated through informal discussions, observation, and anonymous surveys of students.  The student participant pre-and post-experience surveys included questions related to the student’s interest in engineering and engineering research, mentoring experiences, and plans for attending graduate school.  A LinkedIn network was established to maintain contact with REU alumni.

 

Intellectual Merit:

Research activities included design and build experiences, computer simulation, engineering analysis, material characterization and data acquisition.  Each student worked on an individual research project that was part of ongoing research by a graduate student and their work has been included in graduate student theses. In addition, each student documented their research findingsin an extended abstract that was published and presented at the all REU campus wide symposium at the University of Minnesota.  Examples of contributions include: Modelling Solar Windows for Photovoltaics in Buildings and Agriculture, Machine Learning Based Reduction of Soot/NOx Emissions from Engine Combustion, Analysis of Stress States in Spiral-Wound Reverse Osmosis Membranes for Wave-Powered Applications, and Energy Efficiency of Connected and Automated Vehicles (CAVs). 

 

Student responses to pre and post survey questionnaires showed an increase in preparedness to work on projects relate to energy and the environment and an increase in their knowledge on the topic.

 

Broader Impacts:

 

Broader impacts of the program included impacts on climate and energy research, development of communications practices that are appropriate for remote research, and development of skilled engineers with advanced degrees from a diverse population

 

The research itself provides a societal benefit. Each project has valuable societal contributions, for example: clean water through materials development, reduced air pollution through studies of combustion and gas turbines, and energy savings through hybrid wind technology. 

 

The weekly seminar series included a thread on communications, from developing a communication agreement (particularly relevant for remote research), poster development and presentation, maintaining research notes and documenting research as a paper. The communication activities for online participants were developed in coordination with leaders at the Science Museum of Boston, who had developed a communications workshop through the NSF Nanoscale Information Science Education (NISE) network. Thus, communications programming developed for online research from the ME^3 REU program was shared among a broader group of REU programs outside of the University of Minnesota.  

 

The research and professional development activities of the program have helped the students develop lifelong skills including critical thinking, teamwork, and effective communication.  Based on a LinkedIn follow up with all ME^3 students, participants are either still in school (10%), attending graduate school in engineering/science (37%) or working as an engineer (47%).   For comparison, consider that attendance in graduate school is much higher among the REU cohort than for the UMN graduating class of ME students (typically 11.5% go on to graduate school).  Moreover, all participants in the ME^3 REU cohort were from one of or more NSF recognized underrepresented groups.

Modified by: Susan C Mantell
